channel.title: What do you think about Ruby?
channel.description: What do you guys think about Ruby? Is it worth the time reading a book about it or should I focus on studying other languages? Is there much demand for programmers with a knowledge of Ruby? Is Ruby being used for anything else than RoR?

item.title: What do you think about Ruby?
item.dc:creator: @Pwnd Pwnd
item.description:
@Pwnd wrote:

gem install *

Read full topic
item.source: What do you think about Ruby?

item.title: What do you think about Ruby?
item.dc:creator: @EcoPS_GM EcoPS GM
item.description:
@EcoPS_GM wrote:

[quote=“Pwnd, post:22, topic:552451”][quote author=EcoPS GM link=topic=671370.msg4490436#msg4490436 date=1437459879]

Once I realized the power of the syntax, I was hooked. I do freelance RoR work. And the fact that you can find a gem for just about anything. They have some pretty funny gems as well.
It’s handling of collections is amazing, readability is sexy. JRuby is available. I really just like working with it.

https://github.com/rickr/foghorn
One of my favorites.

It’s syntax is nearly spoken.
[/quote]Exactly, and a lot of DSLs will try to maintain that as much as possible. Notably the RSpec testing DSL.[/quote]Which is, of course, a good thing! The better the syntax, the easier the language is to learn.

t4:

quickly, include every gem!

Read full topic
item.source: What do you think about Ruby?

item.title: What do you think about Ruby?
item.dc:creator: @EcoPS_GM EcoPS GM
item.description:
@EcoPS_GM wrote:

Ruby’s a fine language, indeed. It’s syntax is actually quite beautiful, and has the availability to simply ignore common punctual and structural syntax. It’s a powerful, flexible language and I wouldn’t be appalled to the idea of using it, or recommending it. However, just because it has a pretty syntax doesn’t mean it’s a good language, does it?

Compare it to Python - as of 1.8, Ruby has been known to be slower than Python. However, since 1.9, that has been rendered negligible, and 2.0 has seen added performance enhancements. Ruby’s flexibility also allows it to write functions of equivalence in fewer lines of code than Python.

require 'active_support/all'

new_time = 1.month.from_now

[code=python]
from datetime import datetime

from dateutil.relativedelta import relativedelta

new_time = datetime.now() + relativedelta(months=1)[/code]

Notwithstanding - that’s extremely basic code; I’m just providing an example. Either way, Ruby’s a fine language to use.

Read full topic
item.source: What do you think about Ruby?

item.title: What do you think about Ruby?
item.dc:creator: @imthenull imthenull
item.description:
@imthenull wrote:

If you’re looking for a Ruby-esque language, I recommend you try out Crystal. It’s like Ruby, but on steroids.

The Crystal Programming Language

Crystal

Fast as C, slick as Ruby

[ul][li]Ruby-inspired syntax.[/li]
[li]Statically type-checked but without having to specify the type of variables or method arguments.[/li]
[li]Be able to call C code by writing bindings to it in Crystal.[/li]
[li]Have compile-time evaluation and generation of code, to avoid boilerplate code.[/li]
[li]Compile to efficient native code.[/li][/ul]

I believe Crystal uses LLVM as it’s native code assembler, which IMO is a good thing. Please note that this language is in its infancy and is still in an ‘alpha’ stage.

Read full topic

professional ruby programmers are hipsters, or at least every one that i have met. up until 1.9 ruby was slow as fudge. it has some cool features, though.
[/quote]

Isn’t it still slow as fudge?[/quote]
well iirc, 1.8 and previous they were executing directly on the AST rather than compiling to an intermediate.
